FAQ.question: Does an agricultural EC show land classification in Kerala?
FAQ.answer: It may reference land type recorded in the deed, but official classification must be confirmed through revenue records like Thandaper or Village Office records.

FAQ.question: Does the EC list transactions related to farmland leasing or cultivation agreements?
FAQ.answer: Only if such agreements were formally registered. Many informal or oral arrangements will not appear.

FAQ.question: Can EC be used to verify agricultural land for subsidy or farming schemes?
FAQ.answer: It supports ownership validation, but scheme eligibility requires revenue and agricultural records.

FAQ.question: Does the EC show subdivision references if the survey number was split?
FAQ.answer: Yes, if the subdivision is registered with the SRO. Otherwise, survey office records must be checked separately.

FAQ.question: Can agricultural land have registered encumbrances like mortgages?
FAQ.answer: Yes. Banks often mortgage farmland; such entries will appear in EC when legally registered.

FAQ.question: Is EC required to apply for mutation in Kerala?
FAQ.answer: Yes. EC is commonly required along with the Sale Deed when updating ownership in revenue records.

FAQ.question: Does EC verify if the land is eligible for conversion to non-agriculture?
FAQ.answer: No. It only shows transactions. Conversion rules must be checked with revenue and local-body authorities.

FAQ.question: Can EC help verify inherited agricultural land?
FAQ.answer: It can show registered succession deeds, but unregistered inheritance must be confirmed through Village Office records.

FAQ.question: Does the EC reflect government acquisition notices?
FAQ.answer: Only if acquisition entries are formally registered. Separate govt notifications may need manual verification.

FAQ.question: Is the EC from JaaGa authentic?
FAQ.answer: Yes. EC records are sourced directly from Kerala Registration Department without modification.
